title: Revisiting Cambodias Killing Fields 30 years later

tasks.task: Rice cultivation and agricultural recovery in Cambodia after the Khmer Rouge regime.
subtasks: Traversing areas affected by land mines.
Digging irrigation canals under brutal conditions.
Collecting and conserving traditional rice varieties before the conflict.
Planting and reintroducing traditional rice varieties post-war.
Introducing modern irrigation techniques and high-yielding rice varieties (IR 36).
Conducting agronomy research and integrated pest management.
Developing post-harvest technology and mechanization.
Building and training the national agricultural research system (Kadi).
Exporting rice for economic benefit.
Training thousands of Cambodian agriculturalists through various programs.
Establishing partnerships and connections with international scientists.

tasks.task: Capacity building and mentorship of Cambodian researchers.
subtasks: Selecting and training Cambodian researchers at Erie program.
Facilitating advanced education for Cambodian researchers in Australia and other countries.
Encouraging higher education degrees (masters, PhDs) among Cambodian staff.
Facilitating research collaborations and exchange visits.
Supporting the development of the Cambodian Agricultural Research and Development Institute (KADIRI).
Rebuilding and establishing research institutions, such as KADIRI.
Implementing irrigation systems and mechanization.
Constructing facilities for training and research activities.
Clearing and rehabilitating land contaminated with land mines.
Expanding farmland through land reclamation and agriculture development.
Re-establishing traditional and modern agricultural practices.

tasks.task: Monitoring and addressing pest management issues.
subtasks: Developing and implementing integrated pest management strategies.
Monitoring insecticide resistance and disease outbreaks.
Evaluating and introducing new pest control methods.
Collaborating with plant breeders (Ram Chowdhury, Edwin Javier) in varietal development.
Introducing high-yielding Rice Varieties (e.g., IR 36).
Multiplying and distributing seeds to farmers.
Maintaining and conserving seed stocks in the gene bank.
